newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index jumps in early trade.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index jumps in early trade.

text.p: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index jumped 165 points, or 1.31 percent, to 12,746 just after the opening bell on Wednesday in line with Wall Street's big gains overnight, brokers said.
The index eased slightly to trade 158 points higher at 12,741 on light trade of less than HK$500 million.
"Wall Street and futures related activity will give us an extra boost today," said Charles Cheung, executive director at J&A Securities.
"But technically we are still in a trading range of 12,300 to 12,800," Cheung said.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average soared 173.38 points or 2.6 percent to 6,833.59, the second highest point gain in the index's history.
The April Hang Seng Index futures contract opened 220 points higher at 12,790, then eased to trade 155 points up at 12,725.
"There is resistance at 12,800," said one futures trader at an U.S. broker.
Market favourites HSBC Holdings, Sun Hung Kai Properties and Hang Seng Bank led the market.
HSBC led the most active table, gaining HK$2.50 to HK$189.50 on trade of HK$140 million and subsidiary Hang Seng Bank rose HK$1.25 to HK$85.75. Sun Hung Kai Properties put on HK$1.25 to HK81.00.
H shares and red chips were also active. Dongfang Electrical advanced HK$0.175 or 8.05 percent, to HK$2.35 but on low volume of only 412,000 shares.
Shanghai Hai Xing jumped to HK$1.62 then eased to trade HK$0.05 higher at HK$1.56.
Red chip favourite China Resources was actively traded rising HK$0.30 to HK$20.35 on trade of about HK$55.58 million.
CITIC Pacific continued its long recovery, gaining HK$0.20 to HK$40.10.
Going against the trend were Tai Cheung Holdings which lost HK$0.15 to HK$6.10 and Founder (HK) which fell HK$0.15 or 2.86 percent to HK$5.10.
